preface.title: Preface
preface.para: Apache Isis is designed to allow programmers rapidly develop domain-driven applications following the Naked Objects pattern. It is made up of a core framework that supports supports variouys viewers, along with APIs and implementations relating to security, the programming model, the runtime (persistence) and profile stores (user preferences). Apache Isis is hosted at the Apache Foundation, and is licensed under Apache Software License v2.

Isis' json viewer [oai.viewer:json] renders each domain objects as RESTful resources. Each domain object is exposed as an (JSON) resource through HTTP GET and can be used to access other related objects by following links that represent the associations of the domain object. The domain object can be interacted with by modifying its state (through HTTP PUT) or by invoking its actions (through HTTP POST).

sect1.title: Abbreviations used in this Guide
sect1.para:
Apache Isis is built using Maven, which identifies every module with a groupId, an artifactId, a version, and a type. These are called the Maven co-ordinates. In this guide we identify each module using notation (groupId:artifactId); you should assume that the version is the latest version, and the type is the default JAR artifact
Maven modules can create other artifacts too, such as a test JAR artifact. This would be indicated with a type of test-jar. But the default artifact is a regular JAR. . Hence (org.apache.isis:core) is the Maven module with a groupId of org.apache.isis and an artifactId of core.

As a further convenience, we use "oai" as an abbreviation for org.apache.isis. Hence (oai.viewer:json) refers to the parent module for JSON viewer. We also use the "oai" abbreviation within package names.
